I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
multitranche financing facility (MFF) to India for the Infrastructure Development Investment 
Program for Tourism. 
 
2.  The investment program targets inclusive economic growth and provision of livelihood 
opportunities  for  local  communities  in  the  tourism  sector  through  tourism  infrastructure 
development. It will focus on preservation and development of natural and cultural heritage, and 
incidental  services  linked  to  subprojects  including  municipal  services, 1  tourist  support 
infrastructure and services, and tourist destination connectivity infrastructure. The proposed 
MFF is provided to support the four participating states of Himachal Pradesh, Punjab, Tamil 
Nadu, and Uttarakhand to develop the tourism sector as a key driver for economic growth. 
 
II.  THE INVESTMENT PROGRAM 
A.  Rationale 
3.  India has experienced impressive economic growth recently. Gross domestic product 
(GDP) grew at an average annual rate of 7.7% during FY2002–FY2007 and is forecast to 
increase to 8.7% during the 11th Five-Year Plan (2007–2012), making it one of the fast-growing 
economies in the world.  
 
4.  India’s economic growth aims at being inclusive. The percentage of the population below 
the poverty line has declined from 36% in FY1994 to 27.5% in FY2005, but the rate of decline in 
poverty has not kept pace with GDP growth. The rural–urban divide is rapidly rising in India, with 
per capita household expenditure in rural areas estimated at less than half of that in urban 
areas.2 Economic growth across regions has also not been uniform.  
 
5.  However, it is neither easy nor effective to try to reduce the rural–urban disparities by 
stimulating  the  growth  of  the  agriculture  sector  alone.  To  address  the  disparities  more 
effectively, it is important to stimulate the rural non-agriculture sector and the rural service 
sector as a whole to generate more economic and employment opportunities. 
 
6.  Potentially, India is one of the attractive tourist destinations in the world and its tourism 
sector has been growing rapidly. Total foreign tourist arrivals have increased by about 126% 
from 2.38 million in 2002 to around 5.37 million in 2008 (or 14.6% growth per annum). In 2008, 
about $11.75 billion was generated in foreign exchange. Total domestic tourist visits have also 
grown by about 109% from 269.6 million in 2002 to 562.9 million in 2008 (or 13.1% growth per 
annum).3 Virtually every kind of tourism—cultural, religious, eco and adventure, medical, and 
relaxation—has  significant  prospects  in  the  country.  The  richly  varied  developed  and 
undeveloped tourist attractions permit product differentiation and branding. Rapid expansion 
and upgrading of the sector’s infrastructure and services to international standards will increase 
its  attractiveness,  efficiency,  and  competitiveness  against  other  international  destinations,4 
thereby creating significant opportunities for employment generation and growth in livelihood 
programs. 
                                                 
1  Municipal services includes water supply, sanitation, solid waste management, drainage and flood control. 
2  ADB. 2009. Country Partnership Strategy: India, 2009–2012. Manila.

2 
 
7.  In 2002, the government adopted a new policy that recognized tourism as one of the 
sectors with high potential for growth and employment generation, particularly in less-developed 
areas. Based on 2003–2004 surveys, India’s tourism sector contributed only 5.9% of GDP, 
sustaining around 41.8 million people in full-time jobs. However, such a level of contribution to 
GDP by the tourism sector is much lower than the world average of 10.4% in 2007.5 Increased 
investments  in  tourism  can,  therefore,  generate  significantly  more  direct  and  indirect 
employment because of tourism sector’s forward and backward linkages, and contribute to 
mitigating the high levels of rural unemployment and poverty, and the rural–urban inequalities. 
This strategy is reflected in the government’s 11th Five-Year Plan and the Asian Development 
Bank’s  (ADB’s)  India  country  partnership  strategy,  2009–2012  (footnote  2)  that  supports 
development of required urban infrastructure to strengthen the tourism potential of heritage 
cities in an environmentally sustainable manner. 
 
8.  To  this  end,  the  government  committed  to  (i) assisting  the  state  governments  with 
tourism development; (ii) encouraging private sector provision of tourist facilities and services, 
supported by public sector infrastructure development; and (iii) providing regulatory support to 
ensure sustainable tourism. A tourism sector road map for the country, prepared with ADB 
technical assistance (TA) support in the context of the government’s 11th Five-Year Plan, sets 
targets  to  increase  visitor  volumes,  and  their  average  length  of  stay  and  spending,  and 
emphasizes more equitable sharing of tourism benefits with local communities. Under the TA, a 
set of recommendations, which are part of the road map, was also made for capacity building 
and human resource development.6 While the tourism sector’s growth during the 10th Five-Year 
Plan (2002–2007) period was impressive as is mentioned above, 11th Five-Year Plan targets 
were rather ambitious, which included 10 million total international tourist arrivals and 812 
million total domestic tourist visits by 2011, and are turning out to be challenging due to, inter 
alia, the global economic slowdown that started in 2008, badly affecting tourism throughout the 
world. 
 
9.  Private sector participation in the tourism sector is a relatively recent phenomenon in 
India. Many states are still in the transition from service providers to promoters and regulators of 
tourism development with increasingly more private sector service providers actively joining the 
industry.  However,  the  public  sector  still  has  a  significant  role  to  play  in  infrastructure 
development  if  the  economic  potential  of  tourism  is  to  be  realized.  Inadequate  or  poor 
infrastructure connecting the gateways from outside the states and connecting tourist attractions 
within each state, as well as the lack of basic services at tourist destinations—such as water 
supply,  sanitation,  and  solid  waste  management—need  to  be  addressed.  Infrastructure  to 
support community-based tourism is almost absent. 
 
10.  The investment program will assist the government in achieving its targets by tapping 
the tourism sector’s potential to contribute to sustainable and inclusive economic growth. It will 
respond to the urgent need for developing tourism-related infrastructure in the four participating 
states—Himachal Pradesh, Punjab, and Uttarakhand (the three main states of the North West 
Himalayan Heritage Circuit), and Tamil Nadu (the anchor state of the South Heritage Circuit)—
to  promote  the  economic  potential  of  the  tourism  sector  within  a  planned  framework  and 
address  weaknesses  in  management  capacity.  These  four  states  voluntarily  sought  to 
participate  in  the  implementation  of  the  road  map,  and  the  government  supported  their

participation. The government prepared a more specific road map along with a framework for 
necessary  policy  and  sector  reforms  for  each  of  the  four  states  under  follow-up  ADB 
assistance,7 and proposed the MFF modality to support the government’s medium- and long-
term goals. 
 
11.  While infrastructure supporting tourism is being put in place, sector reform must be 
carried out in parallel to attain the goals of more sustainable and inclusive tourism sector 
development. Key challenges include existing limitations in (i) public sector financing; (ii) sector 
policies on, and institutional capacities for, heritage site management; (iii) an effective enabling 
environment  for  enhanced  private  sector  participation;  (iv)  operation  and  maintenance  of 
tourism infrastructure; and (v) effective mechanisms to engage local communities in the tourism 
value chain. Detailed discussions about the national tourism development road map and tourism 
road maps of the four participating states can be found in the framework financing agreement 
(FFA).8 
 
12.  The  investment  program  includes  a  number  of  policy-driven  sector  reforms.  The 
participating states are committed to making investments in the tourism sector more attractive 
for  private  sector  participation.  They  will  also  promote  homestay  programs  and  other 
noncommercial or semicommercial lodging alternatives, such as bed and breakfast facilities. 
Each state will develop a tourism policy to mainstream (i) balanced distribution of economic 
opportunities  across  the  state  through  the  promotion  of  community-based,  tourism-related 
economic and livelihood activities, and ecotourism development; (ii) financial sustainability of 
tourism destinations and their heritage assets, and connectivity infrastructure; and (iii) policy 
and regulatory reforms to provide for adaptive reuse of publicly owned heritage buildings so that 
additional means of cost recovery are established. 
 
13.   The  MFF  modality  is  considered  suitable  for  the  proposed  intervention  because 
developing  the  capacities  of  the  sector  agencies  as  facilitators  and  regulators  of  tourism 
development will be a gradual process requiring longer-term commitments. 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
14.  The  investment  program  will  enhance  the  contribution  of  the  tourism  sector  to 
sustainable  and  inclusive  economic  growth  during  its  10-year  implementation  period.  The 
impact can be assessed by a 50% increase in local employment  created by tourism and 
economic activities linked to tourism in each participating state, and a 30% increase in the 
aggregate contribution of tourism to the GDP of each participating state. The outcome will be 
increased volume of domestic and international tourists. More private sector investments in 
tourism and enhancement of destinations and attractions are also expected.  
 
C.  Outputs 
15.  The investment program outputs will be (i) improved basic urban infrastructure (such as 
water supply, sanitation, road and public transport, solid waste management, and environmental 
improvement) and incidental services (such as public toilets, street signage and lighting) at 
existing and emerging tourist destinations and gateways; (ii) improved connectivity to tourist

attractions focusing on the improvement of last-mile connectivity; (iii) enhanced quality of natural 
and  cultural  tourist  attractions  to  ensure  convenience  and  safety  for  visitors;  (iv) greater 
participation by local communities in tourism-related economic and livelihood activities; and 
(v) strengthened capacity of concerned sector agencies and local communities for planning, 
development, management, and marketing of tourist destinations and attractions, and promoting 
private sector participation and small businesses. 
 
16.  Supporting programs will be established for developing the capacities to promote private 
sector participation and small businesses to increase the benefits they gain from tourism, and 
stimulating  more  active  tourism-related  economic  and  livelihood  activities.  Consultancy  will 
support project implementation and programs for developing the capacities of sector agencies 
for sustainable management of tourism and related infrastructure and services. Two batches of 
subprojects  are  anticipated  from  each  participating  state,  which  the  government  will  then 
consolidate, if applicable, and forward to ADB in the form of periodic financing requests (PFRs). 
The selection criteria set out in the FFA apply to the subprojects to be financed under the 
second tranche onwards and the subprojects under tranche 1 have substantially followed these 
criteria. The first PFR covering the respective first batches of two participating states with 
advanced project readiness (i.e., Himachal Pradesh and Punjab) is processed together with the 
MFF. Five PFRs (including the first one) are anticipated under the investment program.

18.  The government has requested an MFF of up to $250 million equivalent from ADB’s 
ordinary capital resources to help finance a part of the investment program. Processing of five 
tranches is anticipated under the MFF, subject to the government’s submission of related PFRs, 
execution of the related loan and project agreements for each tranche, and fulfillment of terms 
and conditions and undertakings set forth in the FFA. The first tranche of the MFF will have a 
25-year  term,  including  a  grace  period  of  5  years,  an  annual  interest  rate  determined  in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending  facility,  a 
commitment charge of 0.15% per year, and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft 
loan and project agreements. The government will make the relevant portion of the proceeds of 
each  tranche  available  to  each  state  concerned,  promptly  and  on  terms  and  conditions 
acceptable to ADB, for the implementation of the investment program. The financing plan is in 
Table 2.

19.  Project 1. The government has submitted the first PFR in line with the FFA.10 Project 1 
is  estimated  to  cost  $62.03  million  equivalent,  including  taxes  and  duties  of  $6.58  million 
equivalent  to  be  financed  by  the  states.  The  cost  includes  consulting  services  in  detailed 
engineering design, construction supervision, and management, as well as civil works and 
capacity building activities in Himachal Pradesh and Punjab. A loan of $43.42 million from 
ADB’s ordinary capital resources has been requested to cover part of the cost of project 1.

21.  State-level empowered committee. Each state government will establish a state-level 
empowered committee, chaired by the state’s chief secretary and comprising secretaries from 
line agencies, to take all decisions on behalf of the state and will (i) act as a policy making body; 
(ii) provide  overall  advice  and  guidance  to  the  state’s  executing  agency  and  project 
management unit (PMU); and (iii) accord all approvals under the investment program. 
 
22.  Executing agency. The Department of Tourism of each state will be the executing 
agency. All necessary powers to: (i) assume overall responsibility for the execution of the MFF; 
(ii) engage adequate permanent and fixed-term staff to implement the MFF; (iii) set up a state-
level  project  management  unit  (PMU)  and  project  implementation  units  (PIUs);  (iv) provide 
overall strategic guidance on the implementation of the road map; and (v) ensure compliance 
with the loan covenants and undertakings set forth in the FFA will be delegated to the respective 
executing agencies. 
 
23.  Implementing  agency. The Tourism Development Board, or its equivalent, of each 
state will be the implementing agency. 
 
24.  Each PMU will be headed by a full-time project director and will consist of personnel 
deputed from state government departments and recruited from the market. Each PMU will also 
be  supported  by  a  team  of  consultants.  PMU  will  be  the  nodal  agency  for  the  overall 
management of all activities under the investment program and will be responsible for: (i) project 
planning and budgeting; (ii) provision of day-to-day assistance, supervision and guidance for the 
PIUs and their consultants; (iii) review of subprojects’ compliance with ADB’s due diligence 
requirements and approval of subproject proposals submitted by PIUs and state government 
departments; (iv) bidding, evaluation and contract award; (v) management and disbursement of

7 
funds;  (vi) compliance  review  with  loan  covenants,  contract  specifications,  work  plans  and 
quality standards; (vii) consolidation of progress reports, and financial, accounting and audit 
reports; and (viii) coordination regarding matters requiring higher-level decisions of the state-
level empowered committee and ADB. 
 
25.  PIUs will be established in strategic locations in each state for day-to-day management 
of works and capacity building activities. PIUs will mainly consist of engineers and experts 
deputed from state government departments. A team of design and supervision consultants will 
be engaged by the executing agency concerned for each PIU to strengthen its capacity. PIUs 
will be responsible for: (i) prioritizing and preparing subproject proposals; (ii) providing day-to-
day  assistance,  supervision  and  guidance  for  the  design  and  supervision  consultants; 
(iii) conducting detailed assessments and surveys including public consultation and input from 
stakeholders;  (iv) preparing  detailed  designs,  specifications,  schedule  of  quantity,  bidding 
documents,  and  related  documentation;  (v) implementing  civil  works  and  related  activities; 
(vi) reporting to PMU; (vii) preparing regular progress reports for the state-level empowered 
committee,  the  executing  agency  and  ADB  through  PMU;  (viii) supervising  construction, 
conducting quality control, approving progress payments to contractors; and (ix) maintaining 
records and accounts on an up-to-date basis and making these available to ADB for inspection. 
 
26.  Phase 2 of the technical assistance for Preparing the Inclusive Tourism Infrastructure 
Development Project, which focuses on implementation capacity development support to the 
participating states, will cover the initial start-up period of the proposed investment program until 
31  August  2011  (footnote  7).  In  addition  to  the  usual  project  administration  support,  the 
consultants will assist the PMUs and PIUs in the formulation of (i) mobility plans; (ii) possible 
public–private  partnership  schemes;  and  (iii) community  participation  and  capacity  building 
schemes, including promotion schemes for homestay programs and bed and breakfast facilities, 
and training for community-based tourism activities, while letting the staff, private sector parties, 
and communities be exposed to international best practices. Loan-funded consultants will then 
take over the task of implementation support and capacity building for the PMUs and PIUs. 
ADB’s  India  Resident  Mission  will  also  provide  strong  project  administration  support,  in 
particular during the initial start-up period. 
 
III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
27.  Support  with  respect  to  planning  exercises  would  be  necessary,  particularly  in 
addressing  key  issues  such  as  (i) peak-period  visitor  safety  concerns;  (ii) greenfield 
development at prospective tourist destinations, focusing on proper planning and regulations; 
and (iii) mobility and public transport planning in congested areas or mountainous terrain where 
the scope of physical infrastructure improvements is limited, in particular focusing on possible 
adoption of innovative new solutions (i.e., the use of information technology, etc.). In addition, 
public–private partnership contract packaging will be explored in consideration of particular local 
conditions, market conditions, and the level of interest by potential bidders. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
28.  The economic analysis has reviewed11 the following aspects of the investment program: 
(i) the economic rationale for government intervention, (ii) goals, (iii) sector development plans, 
                                                 
11 Analysis on the investment program was carried out in accordance with D. Dole. 2005. Assessing Aid for a Sector 
Development Plan: Economic Analysis of a Sector Loan. ERD Technical Note. No. 14. Manila: ADB.

8 
(iv) associated economic policies, (v) economic risks, (vi) each state government’s capacity, (vii) 
fiscal impact, (viii) each state government’s commitment, (ix) coordination of foreign aid, and (x) 
conditions attached to the loan. The economic rationale for government intervention is justified, 
since the investment program supports basic public services characterized by monopolistic 
conditions, externality management, and impacts on income distribution. 
 
29.  In principle, the participating states will ensure that admission and user fees of tourist 
facilities created or rehabilitated under the investment program are set at levels sufficient to 
make  their  operation  financially  sustainable.  Some  participating  states  intend  to  levy  user 
charges on certain subprojects, such as adaptive reuse of publicly owned heritage buildings for 
commercial purposes. However, most subprojects either cannot earn sufficient revenues or 
directly generate revenues. The participating states will, therefore, ensure that adequate funds 
are provided to meet any shortfall between the costs and revenues for the operation and 
maintenance of those tourist facilities. Most of the proposed subprojects in Himachal Pradesh 
and Punjab under the first PFR are not revenue earning, but the forecast increases in tourist 
visits and incremental tourist spending from longer length of stay will generate higher sales tax 
revenues. The additional budgetary requirements created by the subprojects will not be a 
significant burden for those states, considering their revenue surplus since FY2009. 
 
30.  The  proposed  subprojects  in  Himachal  Pradesh  and  Punjab  under  the  first  PFR 
generate economic benefits in the form of additional tourist spending from the increases in 
tourist volumes and length of stay, and increased revenues from sales taxes due to additional 
international tourist spending. Other quantifiable and unquantifiable economic benefits are also 
expected in the form of enhanced environmental quality and improved access (less travel time 
and vehicle operating costs). Based on the estimated economic benefits, the economic internal 
rates of return for the subprojects under the first PFR were estimated at 14.1% for Himachal 
Pradesh and 22.3% for Punjab.   
 
C.  Governance 
31.  There  is  a  need  to  strengthen  the  financial  management  and  overall  project 
implementation capacities of the executing agencies and implementing agencies. The financial 
management assessment of the investment program showed that there were common financial 
management  challenges  in  the  implementing  agencies  of  each  state,  which  include 
(i) procedures for internal audit; (ii) cash-basis accounting; and (iii) computerization of financial 
management processes. As part of the project management consultancy, financial specialists 
have been included to assist in (i) strengthening internal audit procedures; (ii) studying the 
adoption of accrual-basis (if applicable, double-entry) accounting, and (iii) computerizing the 
project accounting system. Further strengthening of the overall governance will also be explored 
by  facilitating  sound  partnership  arrangements  among  sector  agencies,  local  business 
communities, and local civil societies. These will be addressed during the proposed investment 
program through the capacity building programs for sector agencies. 
 
32.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government and the Department of Tourism of each state. Specific policy requirements 
and supplementary measures are described in the facility administration manual. 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
33.  The poverty and social assessment conducted during investment program preparation 
indicates that poor and marginalized people require skills training and credit for tourism-based

9 
livelihood development. The investment program design, therefore, proposes tourist destination 
enhancement  with  community  participatory  activities  that  support  training  and  local 
entrepreneurship to channel economic benefits directly to the surrounding communities. Poor 
people in these communities will, therefore, benefit from the prospective interventions through 
expanded tourism-related business opportunities, generation of new employment, improved 
living conditions for the local populations, and an increased stake in the management of natural 
and cultural tourism resources. A participation plan under the investment program will facilitate 
such  local  efforts.  The  gender  analysis  conducted  during  investment  program  preparation 
indicates that the sector can provide opportunities for women to participate at all levels. A 
gender action plan was prepared to ensure inclusive social impacts. 
 
E.  Safeguards 
34.  Environment.  Project  1  is  classified  environmental  category  B  and  two  initial 
environmental examinations with environmental management plans were prepared in accordance 
with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). The initial environmental examinations conclude 
that no significant adverse environmental impacts are anticipated, and any impacts during the 
design  and  construction  stages  are  readily  addressed  through  mitigation  measures.  Key 
environmental benefits include improved on-site and off-site hygiene and sanitary conditions at 
tourist destinations, and enhanced conservation through alternative livelihood opportunities in 
ecotourism and increased environmental awareness. All subprojects are consistent with approved 
environmental management plans (which aim to conserve natural tourist attractions) and with 
government environmental regulations. An environmental assessment and review framework was 
prepared to guide environmental assessment in subsequent loans to ensure there are no adverse 
impacts. 
 
35.  Social.  Project  1  is  classified  involuntary  resettlement  category  C  and  indigenous 
peoples category C. Subprojects under project 1 do not result in any physical or economic 
displacement due to involuntary acquisition of land, or involuntary restrictions on land use, or 
more specifically access to the Pong or Keshopur sanctuaries. All land parcels required for 
these subprojects are owned by the respective state governments or implementing agencies. 
There  are  no  indigenous  peoples  in  the  subproject  areas  under  project  1.  Because  no 
involuntary resettlement or impact on indigenous peoples is expected under these subprojects, 
no social safeguards planning documents have been prepared. A resettlement framework and 
an indigenous peoples planning framework have been prepared for future loans, which detail 
screening  and  categorization,  assessment,  planning,  and  institutional  arrangements  and 
processes to be followed.12 Implementation arrangements ensure that PMUs and PIUs have 
adequate capacity to manage social impacts through consultant support and capacity building.

IV.  ASSURANCES 
37.  The government has assured ADB that implementation of the investment program shall 
conform to all applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the facility administration manual and loan documents. 
 
38.  The government and the Department of Tourism, or its equivalent, of each state have 
given ADB certain undertakings for the MFF, which are set forth in the FFA. Specific covenants 
agreed by the government and the Department of Tourism, or its equivalent, of each state with 
respect to individual tranches under the MFF are set forth in the loan agreement and project 
agreement for the respective tranches. 
 
39.  For each “tourist trail” subproject, the relevant PMU will prepare and submit a mobility 
plan before the finalization and issuance of bidding documents to ensure the convenience and 
safety  of  tourists.  The  mobility  plans  must  cover,  among  other  subjects,  public  transport, 
possible pedestrianization (permanent or time-bound) of certain trails, and, where relevant, 
event and crowd management plans for peak periods (e.g., festival periods, auspicious periods 
for pilgrimage). 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
40.  I am satisfied that the proposed multitranche financing facility would comply with the 
Articles of Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board 
approve the provision of loans under the multitranche financing facility in an aggregate principal 
amount not exceeding $250,000,000 to India for the Infrastructure Development Investment 
Program for Tourism from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, with interest to be determined in 
accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility, and such 
other  terms  and  conditions  as  are  substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the 
framework financing agreement presented to the Board.
